controls.code:
control '2_02_subscriptions_roles_overly_permissive' do
  title '2.2 - Azure subscriptions with custom roles should not be overly permissive'
  impact 0.5
  desc 'This policy identifies Azure subscriptions with custom roles are overly permissive.
  Instead of allowing full administrative access Least privilege access rule should be followed and only necessary privileges should be given'
  tag sgs_wiki_url: 'https://wiki.wdf.sap.corp/wiki/x/Ckc3c'
  tag terraform_remediation: <<-EOF
  resource "azurerm_role_definition" "example_role_definition" {
    ...
    permissions {
      actions     = <limited list of actions>
    }
    assignable_scopes = <limited list of scopes>
  }

  EOF
  tag tested_tf_version: '1.0.11'

  tag remediation_steps: <<-EOF
  Check the usage of the role identified and before deleting, check the impact that may be caused by deleting the role. We can't create, update or delete custom roles through the Azure console.
  Use below CLI command to delete the role:

  az role definition delete --name \""rolename\""
  EOF

  azure_role_definitions.where { type == 'CustomRole' }.names.each do |role_def|
    next if role_def == 'd54218c0-97a8-5da8-a483-66a7f7adede9' # Orca role excluded for Shared Tenant.
    next if role_def == 'c702c0ca-1bd9-4353-9f91-6ec883b6ee6d' # Orca role excluded for Corporate Tenant.
    next if role_def == '0b1d2aa3-cbdf-55b8-ad7a-8be9238ff18c' # Orca role excluded for Accenture Tenant.
    next if role_def == '7e9ba4f8-bf8f-4e5d-af02-edc63dc1e801' # Multicloud Security Containment role for Shared tenant
    next if role_def == '41460f83-da15-4fcb-bf6c-921700d4f3be' # Multicloud Security Containment role for Corporate tenant
    next if role_def == '2e8dfdfb-bf5e-4333-9a94-f4af2bcf4dd5' # Orca role excluded for Azure China SAPCN Tenant.
    next if role_def == '1545804c-a7eb-46dd-9061-900047f8d26e' # Orca role excluded for Azure China CDC Tenant.

    role_definition = azure_role_definition(name: role_def)
    next if role_definition.permissions_allowed.nil? || role_definition.assignable_scopes.nil?

    describe "All permissions allowed for role definition ID #{role_def}" do
      subject do
        permissions = role_definition.permissions_allowed
        allow_all_permissions = permissions.select do |permission|
          next if permission.eql?('*/read')

          permission.match?(/^\*/)
        end
        allow_all_permissions.count
      end
      it { should be_zero }
    end
    describe "All scopes allowed for role definition ID #{role_def}" do
      subject do
        scopes = role_definition.assignable_scopes
        allow_all_scopes = scopes.select do |scope|
          scope.eql?('/')
        end
        allow_all_scopes.count
      end
      it { should be_zero }
    end
  end
end

controls.title: 3.2 - Azure Storage account queues logging must be enabled
controls.desc: Storage Account Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to a storage bucket. By enabling Storage Account Logging on all storage accounts, it is possible to capture all events which may affect objects within a target bucket. The log information can be useful in security and incident response workflows. Storage Account Logging MUST be enabled for all storage account queues

1.  Log in to your Azure Subscription, in which the alert exists.
  2.  In the search bar search for storage accounts > click on the resource, for which there is an alert.
  3.  In the Monitoring section on left hand side, click Diagnostic settings.
  4.  Choose queue as the type of storage that you want to enable logs for.
  5.  Click Add diagnostic setting.
  6.  In the Name field of the page, enter a name for this Resource log setting. Then, select StorageRead, StorageWrite, and StorageDelete checkboxes, and where you want the logs to be sent.

control '3_02_storage_account_queues_logging' do
  title '3.2 - Azure Storage account queues logging must be enabled'
  impact 0.8
  desc 'Storage Account Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to a storage bucket. By enabling Storage Account Logging on all storage accounts, it is possible to capture all events which may affect objects within a target bucket. The log information can be useful in security and incident response workflows. Storage Account Logging MUST be enabled for all storage account queues'
  tag sgs_wiki_url: 'https://wiki.wdf.sap.corp/wiki/x/Ckc3c'
  tag terraform_remediation: <<-EOF
  resource "azurerm_monitor_diagnostic_setting" "example_queue_diagnostic" {

    storage_account_id         = <name of the storage account where the logs will be stored>

      category = "StorageRead"
      enabled  = true
    }
    log {
      category = "StorageWrite"
      enabled  = true
    }
    log {
      category = "StorageDelete"
      enabled  = true
      }
  }
  EOF
  tag tested_tf_version: '1.0.11'

  tag remediation_steps: <<-EOF
  1.  Log in to your Azure Subscription, in which the alert exists.
  2.  In the search bar search for storage accounts > click on the resource, for which there is an alert.
  3.  In the Monitoring section on left hand side, click Diagnostic settings.
  4.  Choose queue as the type of storage that you want to enable logs for.

  azure_storage_accounts.entries.each do |azure_storage_account_data|

      it { should have_queues_read_log_enabled }
      it { should have_queues_write_log_enabled }
      it { should have_queues_delete_log_enabled }
    end
  end
end

controls.title: 3.3 - Azure SQL auditing must be enabled
controls.desc:
Audit logs can help you find suspicious events, unusual activity, and trends to analyze database events. Auditing the SQL Server, at the server-level,
  enables you to track all new and existing databases on the server. This policy identifies SQL servers/databases which do not have auditing enabled. As a best practice,
  enable auditing on each SQL server so that the database are audited, regardless of the database auditing settings.

descriptions.default:
Audit logs can help you find suspicious events, unusual activity, and trends to analyze database events. Auditing the SQL Server, at the server-level,
  enables you to track all new and existing databases on the server. This policy identifies SQL servers/databases which do not have auditing enabled. As a best practice,
  enable auditing on each SQL server so that the database are audited, regardless of the database auditing settings.

tags.remediation_steps:
1.  Log in to your Azure Subscription, in which the alert exists.
  2.  In the search bar search for SQL servers/databases > click on the resource, for which there is an alert.
  3.  On left hand side under Security heading, click Auditing > Set the Enable Azure SQL Auditing parameter.
  4.  Click on Save.

controls.code:
control '3_03_sql_auditing_enablement' do
  title '3.3 - Azure SQL auditing must be enabled'
  impact 0.8
  desc 'Audit logs can help you find suspicious events, unusual activity, and trends to analyze database events. Auditing the SQL Server, at the server-level,
  enables you to track all new and existing databases on the server. This policy identifies SQL servers/databases which do not have auditing enabled. As a best practice,
  enable auditing on each SQL server so that the database are audited, regardless of the database auditing settings.'
  tag sgs_wiki_url: 'https://wiki.wdf.sap.corp/wiki/x/Ckc3c'
  tag terraform_remediation: <<-EOF
  resource "azurerm_mssql_database_extended_auditing_policy" "example_auditing_policy" {
    database_id                             = <your database id>
    storage_endpoint                        = <your storage account endpoint>
    storage_account_access_key              = <your storage account access key>
    ...
  }
  resource "azurerm_mssql_server_extended_auditing_policy" "example_server_auditing_policy" {
    server_id                  = <your server id>
    storage_endpoint           = <your storage account endpoint>
    storage_account_access_key = <your storage account access key>
  }
  EOF
  tag tested_tf_version: '1.0.11'

  tag remediation_steps: <<-EOF
  1.  Log in to your Azure Subscription, in which the alert exists.
  2.  In the search bar search for SQL servers/databases > click on the resource, for which there is an alert.
  3.  On left hand side under Security heading, click Auditing > Set the Enable Azure SQL Auditing parameter.
  4.  Click on Save.
  EOF

  azure_resource_groups.names.each do |resource_group|
    azure_sql_servers(resource_group: resource_group).names.each do |sql_server|
      az_sql_server = azure_sql_server(resource_group: resource_group, name: sql_server)
      if az_sql_server.auditing_settings.properties.state == 'Enabled'
        describe az_sql_server do
          its('auditing_settings.properties.state') { should cmp 'Enabled' }
        end
      else
        azure_sql_databases(resource_group: resource_group, server_name: sql_server).names.each do |sql_databse|
          az_sql_database = azure_sql_database(resource_group: resource_group, server_name: sql_server, name: sql_databse)
          next if az_sql_database.name == 'master'
          next unless az_sql_database.exists?

          describe az_sql_database do
            its('auditing_settings.properties.state') { should cmp 'Enabled' }
          end
        end
      end
    end
  end
end

controls.title: 3.3 - Azure SQL auditing retention must be enabled for at least 180 days
controls.desc:

  newly created databases on the instance. This policy identifies SQL servers which do not retain audit logs for more than 180 days. As a best practice,
  configure the audit logs retention time period to be at least 180 days.

controls.code:
control '6_03_app_gateway_tls' do
  impact 0.8
  title '6.3 - Azure Application Gateway must not allow invalid TLS'
  desc <<-DESC
  Azure Application Gateway is a layer 7 Loadbalancer that distributes incoming traffic among healthy virtual machine instances.
  SSL policy MUST be configured to use TLS 1.2 or higher.
  DESC
  tag sgs_control_hash: '8ae223887226fcbd01722703b9830022'
  tag sgs_wiki_url: 'https://wiki.wdf.sap.corp/wiki/x/Ckc3c'
  tag terraform_remediation: <<-EOF
  resource "azurerm_application_gateway" "example_gateway" {
    ...
    ssl_policy {
      # min_protocol_version = "TLSv1_2"
      policy_name = "AppGwSslPolicy20170401S"
      policy_type = "Predefined"
    }
  }
  EOF
  tag tested_tf_version: '1.0.11'
  tag terraform_remediation_note: 'If a custom configuration is used instead of a predefined policy type, the minimum protocol version must be configured'

  tag remediation_steps: <<-EOF
  To set the SSL policy using the predefined policy, please run the following command:

  az network application-gateway ssl-policy set -g <resource_group_name> --gateway-name <app_gateway_name> -n AppGwSslPolicy20170401S --policy-type Predefined

  Refer to <https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/application-gateway/application-gateway-ssl-policy-overview> for more information and for a list of the available predefined policy.
  EOF

  # Azure Application Gateways can have default, predefined or custom SSL policies
  # https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/application-gateway/application-gateway-ssl-policy-overview
  # They are defined for the entire application gateway, not per listener.
  #
  # Default policy is configured when sslPolicy does not exist in the properties collection
  #
  # Predefined names:
  # AppGwSslPolicy20150501  (TLS v1.0 minimum)
  # AppGwSslPolicy20170401  (TLS v1.1 minimum)
  # AppGwSslPolicy20170401S (TLS v1.2 minimum) - Only permissible policy
  #
  # Custom policies can define minimum protocol versions and desired cipher suites

  azure_resource_groups.names.each do |resource_group|
    azure_application_gateways(resource_group: resource_group).names.each do |lb_name|
      describe.one do
        describe azure_application_gateway(resource_group: resource_group, application_gateway_name: lb_name) do
          its('properties.methods') { should include :sslPolicy }
          its('properties.sslPolicy.policyType') { should eq 'Predefined' }
          its('properties.sslPolicy.policyName') { should eq 'AppGwSslPolicy20170401S' }
        end

        describe azure_application_gateway(resource_group: resource_group, application_gateway_name: lb_name) do
          its('properties.methods') { should include :sslPolicy }
          its('properties.sslPolicy.policyType') { should eq 'Custom' }
          its('properties.sslPolicy.minProtocolVersion') { should eq 'TLSv1_2' }
        end
      end
    end
  end
end
